awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Environmental Sustainability of Next Generation Lithium Ion Batteries for Electric Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration: 1351602 (Yuan).  The research objectives of this CAREER grant are to investigate the environmental sustainability of next generation lithium ion batteries (NG LIBs) and to create a sustainability analysis tool for sustainable design and manufacturing of NG LIBs for battery-powered electric vehicles (BEVs), collaborating with General Motors, Johnson Controls, and PE International. More specifically, the research objectives of this career grant include: (1) Modeling and investigations of NG LIB manufacturing emissions; (2) Experimental investigations of nano-particle emissions from NG LIB manufacturing through in situ and ex situ techniques; (3) Thermodynamic energy modeling and validation of NG LIB manufacturing; (4) Closed loop sustainability management of NG LIB technologies through recycling and sustainability analysis tool development. The long-term educational goal is to establish a comprehensive educational program on environmental sustainability of BEVs. To fulfill this goal, the educational objectives of this CAREER grant are to provide cutting-edge research-based knowledge and educational resources for environmental sustainability of NG LIBs. The educational plans of this proposal include: (1) Students' education and training through curriculum development and research participation; (2) Industrial professionals? education and outreach through industrial seminars, short course and conference seminars;(3) General public education and awareness through online videos, public radio programs and website downloadable materials. Major innovations of the project include the development of process-based mathematical models and tools validated through experimentation for understanding and improving the environmental sustainability of NG LIB technology. The project aims to lead to the development and application of NG LIB technology in large-scale industrial production with reduced environmental impacts and economic costs. NG LIB is under development using nanotechnologies which have significant sustainability issues in real production. Moreover, nano-wastes and nano-particle emissions from NG LIB productions may pose severe risks of exposure for both occupational and public health. In addition, NG LIB production is very energy-intensive, which contributes not only to the environmental impacts, but also to the high costs of NG LIB products. This project aims to reduce NG LIB manufacturing wastes and emissions (including nano-particle emissions), improve the energy efficiency, and enhance the sustainable development of NG LIB technology for future large-scale applications on EVs. Environmental sustainability performance of NG LIB technologies is significant and must be fully investigated and improved before large-scale application in future EVs. The research results will be broadly disseminated through academic journals, conference proceedings, internet media, etc., and will improve people's understanding about the potential environmental impacts of NG LIB technology and assist in developing a sustainable infrastructure for NG LIB production for EVs. In practice, the research results will be applied by industrial partners (GM and JC). The educational impact includes involving high school students and teachers, developing a new course on sustainable design and manufacturing, integrating the research results into two current UWM courses (enrolling more than 120 students/year), teaching a short course in the UWM School of Continuing Education for local and national industrial professionals, offering the course materials through UWM's online MS program, holding seminars at leading industrial companies (GM and JC) and premiere conference workshops (ISSST), sharing the materials in such national high-impact databases and websites as NSDL and NCLT, and offering video and public radio programs for the general public. This project will train one postdoc, one Ph.D. student and two undergraduate students (with the support of NSF REU and UWM SURF programs). Underrepresented students will be recruited from UWM student professional societies. The educational materials will be shared with the PI's collaborators in both the U.S. and China.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Electric vehicles (EVs) are widely recognized as clean alternatives to conventional vehicles in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from ground transportation. Current EVs are all powered by lithium ion batteries but the energy density of the current lithium ion batteries is not high enough to power EVs for a long driving distance. In recent years, next generation lithium ion batteries have been pursued under intensive research and development through nano-scale science and technologies to increase the storage capacity and improve the energy density, aiming at future large-scale applications on electrical vehicles. While various nano-scale science and technologies have been demonstrated on their potentials in improving the storage capacity and energy density of lithium ion batteries, these lithium ion batteries based on nanomaterials and nanotechnologies have significant issues in their environmental sustainability performance due to the heavy use of toxic chemicals, large consumptions of energy, and generation of nanomaterial wastes and nano-particle emissions. This CAREER project aims to study the environmental sustainability of next generation lithium ion batteries based on silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes, specifically, on mathematical modeling and experimental testing of environmental emissions from LIB manufacturing, nanowastes and nanoparticle emissions, energy analysis and energy-related environmental impacts, sustainability management and life cycle impact assessments.

In this project, the environmental sustainability of next generation lithium ion batteries based on silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes has been systematically studied through both mathematical modeling and experimental investigations. First, all the materials used in synthesis of the silicon nanowire and silicon nanotubes have been analyzed following the material flows and experimentally measured for their quantities and compositions. The emissions to the environment have been experimentally studied for both gaseous emissions and aqueous wastes. The synthesized silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes were characterized with advanced analytical techniques for their sizes, morphologies, structure and compositions, using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), Energy-dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS), etc. Then the synthesized silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes were fabricated into lithium ion battery cells, following the standard manufacturing processes from mixing, coating to final assembly. The fabricated lithium ion batteries were tested for their electrochemical performance. The materials consumed and wastes generated in synthesizing the silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes were analyzed based on the specific capacity of the lithium ion battery cells being tested.  Second, the nanomaterial wastes and nanoparticle emissions generated from the synthesis processes of the silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes have been studied using both in-situ and ex-situ techniques on the number concentrations of nanoparticle emissions, size distributions of nanoparticle emissions, morphologies and chemical compositions of the aqueous nanowastes. In order to understand the energy consumption and energy-related impacts, a unit energy analysis model has been developed for the lithium ion battery manufacturing processes, incorporating the silicon nanowires and silicon nanotube synthesis processes. A life cycle energy analysis model has been developed to study the embodied energy and primary energy demand of the silicon nanowires, silicon nanotubes, as well as other materials, components and processes of the lithium ion battery cells. The associated environmental impacts throughout the life cycle of the lithium ion batteries fabricated with the silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes were evaluated through a comprehensive life cycle assessment approach for their applications on electric vehicles, and compared with those of conventional lithium ion batteries used in current electric vehicles, from cradle to grave. Finally, the research results accomplished in this project has been developed into an environmental sustainability analysis tool to support the sustainable development of next generation lithium ion batteries on silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes.

In summary, this project has performed a fundamental and systematic study on the potential environmental sustainability of next generation lithium ion batteries based on silicon nanowires and silicon nanotubes for use on electric vehicles. Dozens of journal papers, conference presentations, invited talks and news reports have been delivered to the public and research communities out of this project. A number of graduate students, postdoc researchers and undergraduate students have participated in this research project. The research results accomplished in this project can support the sustainable development of next generation lithium ion batteries for their applications on electric vehicles in future.    

 


Last Modified: 04/15/2022
Modified by: Chris Y Yuan
